posts.content: Now, I know I have a few requirements to meet before a build can be made (PvM, PvP) that sort of stuff. But, before I went through that process, I wanted to ask the experts in the community. Is it feasible (realistically viable) to make a magical swordsman (as in) I mean a (elven race) Rogue/Wizard or Fighter/Wizard (Within a cap of 30). I ask out of curiousity mostly to try and figure out about what 'type' of build I would like help in making. I would prefer a response, so that I might make a 'temp' build and get some appopriate help on it. If it's not at all 'workable' I'd also want that honest opinion so that I might change it up a bit and then present a new build for inspection.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
You probably mean a "Elven spellsword", an offensive caster that supplements the spell repertoire with a melee attack if so edit your topic title to reflect that, please.  If that is what you mean, the answer is: Of course.  Race has no bearing on whether a spellsword is viable or not.  Elves simply get one less pre-feat, fewer skills and a more finicky favored class to manage is all.  But Keen Sense and some of the other racial bonuses can make up for the trade-off.  It's really no more complicated than that.

But you are going to need to be more specific about where and how you intend to play this toon.
 
What is the max magic level of gear enhancements?
Is there a lot of dispel spamming on that server?
Weapon/shield or dual-wield as your preference?
Keep in mind that any arcane spellsword is subject to casting failure so armor, shield and still spells will factor in.  In most cases, without still or autostill, your toon will cast more reliably just going with robes and using a two-end weapon or other dual-wield set up rather than gearing a shield.
Any class bans or nerfs like RDD, PM, SD or others?

But all that sort of deliberation can wait until you've clearly defined your intent, the limitations and/or bonuses that apply on your PW and your own playstyle (are you comfortable spending time self-buffing? do you plan to use your familiar for recon? do you have problems using summons in combat situations?... just general biases that may affect how a design is utilized).

Yes, "Elven Spellsword" That's exactly what I was thinking. Thank you for reminding me of the name xD
I Intend to play on Arelith (Lv. 30 Cap.) (Hey, its RP and its got a lot of players, hopefully its a good home for me ^^) Figured I'd answer everything in one go!!

Max Magic Level on gear? I don't know this. I do know that rings and such can at least get +1 on main stats and skills get +2? You can possibly enchant an item with everything, but I think the maximum possible with great success is two. However, it could be higher on high levels. The Max I heard of on an item was a +4 to a stat and it was a rare type deal (outside of crafting from other players) So, I'd assume +1 unless you get a talented player to craft stuff?

Is there a lot of dispel spamming on the server? Sorta. With the correct number of UMD  everyone and their grandmother could spam the living crap out of you with scrolled (and possibly wands) Mord's. Shadowdancer gets HIPS at level 5 instead of 1. Shadow evade lasts three rounds per class level instead of just 5. And +1 in hide for every level.

My familiar for recon? Yeah, I guess it's possible to do such a thing, but I kinda like the pixie type deal. (You know, it also being a rogue and such) As for summons, I don't think there's much an issue. For each conjuration focus you get more powerful summons. Ex. Spell Focus Conjuration: Giving you a level two summon instead of a level one (Greater) turning it into a three instead of 1. (Of course, epic furthers even level 9 summons I hear as well) Now, as a spell sword, I feel like I'd be doing more melee itself than spellcasting. But, I don't want either to be obsolete because of the other (though, if I have to focus in more one than the other) I'd like to be more on the spell side than the melee side.

As a note: I want to get up to at least Epic Conjuration and Epic Evocation (if possible). All other feats are okay, but if wizard becomes the first level then Conjuration and Greater would be a must in the 1st and third levels as (its really the only way you can survive xD) If possible, I'd love to get Epic weapon focus Rapier as well, but that might be asking for too much.

posts.content:
Okie doke.  That's all very helpful.  It's not a replacement for you building your own toons to your own specifications but through testing and modifications, one of us can approximate a "best fit" for your style.

I am somewhat aware of the nuances on Arelith, like that 3-consecutive-class level deal but will rely on your input to fashion one that works as planned.  I'll ask you to study the spell changes yourself, mainly because you'll be the one playing it and secondly because I just don't have the time to read and ruminate over custom server information, short or otherwise. I'm being honest.  Just too little time to check the boards and quickly piece something together so bear with me.

The dispel info is important.  What that means is that you will need a minimum of 24 caster levels to avoid getting dispelled by anything but a Mord.  There's no point trying to reach immunity to a Mord on a Level 30 server because it is not possible.  You'll just have to accept those situations and design a contingency plan (like casting Greater Sanctuary and running away to rebuff).

I see two key variants:  a skilled, versatile one and one with divine bonuses and taunt.  The skilled version would be a Wiz24/Rog3/Ftr3 and the other would be Src24-25/Pal5-6 (figuring on at least one epic discipline and taunt dump).

You'll notice that the divine one cannot achieve both relative indispellability plus Div Might/Shield and still have room for a tumble class on a level 30 PW with the 3-level anti-dump cheese minimum.  You can make up for the lost tumble AC via Div Shield but it will be limited by Turn Undead attempts whereas the tumble AC is static.

The Wiz version will get more casting feats and a full repertoire of spells (depending on how many scrolls are available on Arelith) to learn those spells not acquired during level-up.  It will rely on the increased Spellcasting skill (INT-based) to compensate for some of the saves vs. spells that Divine Grace provides (actually those are universal saves that can be converted into spell saves).  With rogue dumps, it can be sculpted into a high-stealth caster and UMD-user of class-specific gear and divine wands/scrolls etc.  You can build a smite-proof Wiz/Rog/Ftr.

The Src version will gain the benefit of those saves mentioned before plus divine damage (Div Might) that can penetrate any DR and divine AC, neither of which can be dispelled even by a Mord.  You'll need to choose a balanced repertoire of both melee buffs and offensive spells since the known list is limited by the class.  Perhaps other sorc players can recommend a reliable mix because I don't play sorc spellswords myself.  But I am sure there is an optimal arrangement that can be used effectively.  The Src/Pally will be smite bait vs. all BGs.  There's no way around that, unfortunately.

Those are the two choices that come to mind.  Each has its merits and limitations.  You could also manufacture a bardic spelIsword but that is a whole other path. I (and other guild members) can help you design either one but like I said, choosing spells for the sorc is problematic for me.  I am more acclimated to slotting the best spells for each occasion with a wizard and then readjusting as new situations arise.

I've already got the majority of changes down myself, I merely put that down so that you could see as well (as me putting it down here would be equally time consuming to read I imagine ^^)

Whilst I think everyone casting a Mord isn't going to be a super common occurrence, unless they're not only rich (to scribe or buy), but also need the required...spell caster.

Now, that you bring up sorcerer. There are some changes to it, that whilst optional may or may not benefit the build as a whole. I will post the changes below.
Sorcerer Changes:

The Path of the True Flame can be chosen at character creation by sorcerers. Followers of the Path of the True Flame get unlimited spells per day, but can cast only evocation spells. This limitation includes spells cast from scrolls, wands, and items like potions; Mundane items, however, are the exception to the rule. Epic spells must also only be Evocation (this means Greater ruin and Hellball) however they can only be cast once per rest as per normal.


Weave Master can be chosen at character creation by sorcerers. Weave masters get unlimited spells per day however they have a cool-down for all spells above the first level. The Cooldown formula is: (Spell level -1)*6 seconds.Example 1: 1st lvl spell (spell level of 1 -1 = 0) *6 seconds = 0 second cool-down (so you can cast 1st lvl spells normally as often as you want)Example 2: 5th lvl spell (spell level of 5 -1 = 4) *6 seconds = 24 second cool-down (hope that spell was worth it!)The cooldown timer is based on the spell slot, and not the actual spell itself. So spells modified with metamagic will increase the cooldown accordingly.Please note:
  • The metamagic Feat "Quicken Spell", when used to cast a spell, will reduce the effective level of the spell by 1 when calculating cooldowns.
  • Auto Quicken I: Spells of level 2-3 no longer have cooldown.
  • Auto Quicken II: Spells of level 4-6 count as 2 levels lower, for the purpose of cooldown.
  • Auto Quicken III: Spells of level 7-9 count as 3 levels lower, for the purpose of cooldown.
I don't know if this would be relevant in helping or not. But, those changes do allow one to not worry on terms of having some 'castable' spells. They will always have 'something' available. But, each one has a pro and con. True Flame cannot cast buffs and the like, nor use potions, scrolls, or wands that are not evocation. (So, no healing potions) Weave Master, allows all spells to be cast unlimited, but at the cost of a small- to large, cooldown as seen above. With a way to possibly lower said cooldown.


The Wizard has no such changes, as only spells and feats themselves have been changed (Necromancy giving more undead. Others giving the ability to scry, or teleport, etc once per rest.) Only Epic Evocation or Epic Conjuration have any real term benefit (such as hellball or greater ruin doing massive amounts more damage than Original, or increased stronger summons) So, the Sorcerer could be a better alternative, but I want your opinion as well.

I do want to say in order to cast spells the 'base' stats must be met. So, let's say you need 13 INT to cast a level 4 spell on a wizard. Your base needs to be 13, it cannot be 8 and then increased to 13 via items. I do, however, want the Rapier incorperated as well. One of the above would allow for a steady stream of spells, but only if Sorcerer is taken first.


Edit: Went to test and confirm True Flame cannot use any spells other than evocation, and no healing potions. However, they are able to utilize healing kits as  a means for healing if need be.

I've numbered your comments just to make it easier to respond.

1.  When I stated a rapier could not be keened, I meant via the arcane spell Keen Edge.  I realize that some environments provide the Keen property on weapons that should logically not be able to increase their effectiveness by sharpening the edge (i.e. slash) like clubs or whips or rapiers (only the tip is used), but I build independent of the gear for the most part.  Weapon enhancement is the one exception because a +5 weapon can penetrate Stoneskin whereas a +3 cannot and must rely on either crits or other means (like divine damage) to bypass the DR.  That is important to know when you are depending on a spell like GMW to gain that advantage, one that fighters may not have.

2. I don't see any advantage of increasing WIS to 10 or the odd level on INT, 15.  INT 14 would allow a discipline dump on the final pally level, but it looks like you are draining your primary attack ability (STR) for some reason that I can't understand, just for the sake of 33 skill points.  Besides that, take a look at your HP tally at CON 10. 156 for a Level 30 toon!  Ouch.  And Fort save is one of the worse to gimp.  Not a good idea.

3. Paladin is the synergy class for sorcerer. You gain add'l saves by the CHA modifier and open up access to the divine buffs.  There are only 2 other classes that can access those buffs/feats, Blackguard and Cleric (must be able to turn undead).  BG requires Cleave, BAB 6 and 5 ranks of Hide, all of which are beyond this build's capacity.  In any event, even if you xclassed Hide and shoved Cleave in there, your divine buffs wouldn't be available until near the end of pre-epic.  Cleric is a 3/4 class so it is likely your pre-epic BAB would be 10 (Src17/Clc3) for only 2 APR but without Divine Power. If you know of another class that synergizes with sorc better than pally, I am all ears.

Empower Spell is possibly the strongest metamagic feat available.  But you need to know how to use it.  Look at the abilities first.  Slot 2 ability buffs have a maximum bonus of +2.  Empowered slot 4 ability buffs have a maximum bonus of +3.  That a full point more on every ability which means  (in this build, specifically) an extra +1 dmg, +1 AB, +1 DEX AC, +1 Reflex, +1 DEX skills, +30 HP, +1 Fort, +1 Conc, +1 Will, +1 INT skills (like Lore, Spellcraft), +1 Divine AC, +1 Divine Dmg, +1 universal saves, +1 round divine buff duration.  I think I remembered most of them.  With a favorable roll a damage spell like Empowered IGMS reaches it highest level possible, 360 whereas Maximize is guaranteed to cause no more than 240.  I could go through the entire arsenal of benefits but your own experience combined with a close look on the combat log will itemize what the benefits are.

4.  Hmmm.  Do you really understand how the attack roll and threat range works?  A +2 AC that cannot be dispelled or lost while flanked or flat-footed is HUGE!  Try looking at it this way:  If an opponent is able to hit you without needing a natural 20, let's say can hit you with rolls 15 to 19... every +1AC you add to your toon reduces the chance the foe will hit you by 5%.  Instead of a 25% chance to hit, it becomes 15%.  So Armor Skin guarantees you will be hit 10% less than without it.   As far as figuring out the ABs you are dealing with, keep checking the combat log.  Unless you are clairvoyant or know the AB ratings of every creature on the server, it highly unlikely, that anyone can figure out an "ideal" AC to aim for in any transitive environment, especially when the DMs are spawning unique creatures all the time (well, where I play they take an active part... not sure about Arelith).  Since this toon is at least a part-time meleer, it should be a priority to increase your chances of avoiding every attack you can.

5.  If you can reach the ability class by means other than ability buffs, fine.  So you can cap every ability on Arelith?  If you can, it still stacks with the intrinsic ability so you want it as high as possible.

Arelith sounds more like a high-magic server than a mid-magic one to me the more I hear about all the customizations.  Just happens to level cap at 30 is all. Nobody buffs anything in high-magic realms and you see no clerics, no wizards, no sorcerers either.  I mean, what's the point? All the power spells are available on items along with spell immunities and ridiculous SR ratings.  All skill caps can be reached via items props.  So you see nothing but WMs and AAs running around fighting creatures near impossible to hit without an AB at least 60.  Does Arelith really think that balance is achieved by item props?  *sigh*  Sounds like a toon designer's nightmare to me.

1. Alright, I took a little read over your stuff. It looks good. But, a Rapier can indeed be keened (it requires 2000 gold and level 3 to wield), but that's pretty simple to get considering its so early on!

2. I've been taking a look over the class changes, and the spell changes. Trying to figure out what might be best to benefit, or outright do things. I know Wizard is a better choice between the two mostly. But, it's (so common) I wanted to do something different.

I was wondering how different the build would go if we did it like this for the Sorcerer (Note the changes below and give your opinion)
STR: 12 +2
DEX: 10
CON: 10
WIS: 10
INT: 15
CHA: 16

3. Unless, the paladin can be replaced with something more.
My reasoning for this is Empowered spell isn't going to be helpful in a lot of cases (Spell Focus offers more benefits long term), even Extend or Still spell might be better.

4.Armor Skin does give a +2 AC, but that 2 AC will not really make the difference between getting hit or not. (Even though it can stack with others)

5.Now, why 12 STR instead of 16 that is presented above. Because, 12 strength with enchanted items +1 in strength in all 'equipment, accessory slots, minus arrows etc.) Can net anywhere between 10-11 STR before Bull Strength itself increasing it further. It would be a bit expensive to get there, but its completely doable.


Now do correct me if I'm wrong! I'm only trying to get the maximum potential out of the build, whilst twisting the mechanics for Arelith to my advanatage, sorta xD
I've numbered your comments just to make it easier to respond.

1.  When I stated a rapier could not be keened, I meant via the arcane spell Keen Edge.  I realize that some environments provide the Keen property on weapons that should logically not be able to increase their effectiveness by sharpening the edge (i.e. slash) like clubs or whips or rapiers (only the tip is used), but I build independent of the gear for the most part.  Weapon enhancement is the one exception because a +5 weapon can penetrate Stoneskin whereas a +3 cannot and must rely on either crits or other means (like divine damage) to bypass the DR.  That is important to know when you are depending on a spell like GMW to gain that advantage, one that fighters may not have.

2. I don't see any advantage of increasing WIS to 10 or the odd level on INT, 15.  INT 14 would allow a discipline dump on the final pally level, but it looks like you are draining your primary attack ability (STR) for some reason that I can't understand, just for the sake of 33 skill points.  Besides that, take a look at your HP tally at CON 10. 156 for a Level 30 toon!  Ouch.  And Fort save is one of the worse to gimp.  Not a good idea.

3. Paladin is the synergy class for sorcerer. You gain add'l saves by the CHA modifier and open up access to the divine buffs.  There are only 2 other classes that can access those buffs/feats, Blackguard and Cleric (must be able to turn undead).  BG requires Cleave, BAB 6 and 5 ranks of Hide, all of which are beyond this build's capacity.  In any event, even if you xclassed Hide and shoved Cleave in there, your divine buffs wouldn't be available until near the end of pre-epic.  Cleric is a 3/4 class so it is likely your pre-epic BAB would be 10 (Src17/Clc3) for only 2 APR but without Divine Power. I shall number in points in order for you to understand which of yours I am talking about.


1. True, but all I was saying was it has keen on there. How far enchantments can go? I cannot say.

2. Wisdom is to balance it out. I'm not 100% worried about advantages or disadvantages. Strength can be increased via a gift to 14. That takes care of the 13+ requirement for the divine might, etc abilities. In term, a +1 to strength on each item brings it well beyond the 20 points you aimed for in the build. Without sacrificing natural points given to other aspects. Constitution could be higher I admit, but I've already figured I'm going to just weapon focus in Rapier, and focus on Spellcasting for the sorcerer the other amount of the way.

3. There is indeed great Synergy with a Paladin and Sorcerer. It works pretty well with a monk as well in which is how I got to those saves. With a favorable roll on IGMS, I could not reach its true potential. Casting IGMS on Arelith, is not really any better than ILMS since they limited the magical bolts per one person (10). You do potentially do slightly more damage, but the big change itself isn't noticeable without all the magical balls striking the enemy. (Though, I apologize, I thought maxamize spell wass better than Empowered, hence why I was thinking of changing it.)

4. Do I know how the attack role works? Somewhat. Threat Range: That was something new to me. I thank you for the lesson. It's definitely random when it comes to these things. You have your insane AB guys, your higher than puffy dragon AC guys, a bunch of mixtures on Arelith. (They're all mostly power builders though, so.. go figure xD)

5. Theoretically? Yes, you could do that. Realistically? No, I think you're missing the point. When I say +1 on strength, I mean a ring getting +1. Yes, when you add up all the items if they all have strength on it. It does indeed seem like a lot. Enchanting an item with more than 2 buffs (Stat, Skill, etc) without a 80-90% Chance of major failure (Gold loss, Heavy exp loss, etc) Not likely. Possible, but unlikely. Arelith is still pretty much a low magic realm. You don't just find magical items out in the world willy nilly like the OC, or some other persistent worlds. But, with risk comes ...semi-rewards. It does seem like a nightmare, but its still surprisingly balanced. Nobody's character will go without being put in the dirt more than a few times. You might be overthinking things, it's not all about balance, it's whether you have fun playing or not. ...Except you know, when DM's decide to spawn 10 Balors in the noob town for story purposes. Things get hectic pretty quickly.


Anyway, thank you for your time. I enjoyed myself and even figured out how I want to build this Sorcerer.
